sentence.idiomatic: Ms. Wang is in a great mood today.
How is the boss's mood today? Not so good.
Staying in a good mood is very helpful for one's health.
Did Mr. Li pass the exam? Yes.
If you don't study hard, you won't be able to pass the exam.
I'm in a bad mood because I didn't pass my exam.
Why is Ms. Zhang disappointed? Because her boyfriend didn't call her.
The boss is really disappointed with Mr. Li's work.
That movie is boring. It really disappointed me.
Mr. Wang plans to put a lot of effort into studying French.
Did Ms. Zhang put a lot of effort into learning how to interact socially? Yes.
Ms. Li learned to speak German without putting much effort into it.
He might not come because he doesn't like parties.
Can Mr. Li possibly finish this work within three days? Impossible.
Ms. Wang can't possibly be at the office now. I just saw her went out.
When he was little he lived in Shanghai.
When Ms. Wang was in school she liked studying mathematics.
When you were in Hong Kong did you see Mr. Li? No.
Are you nervous when you take a test? A little.
With Mr. Wang here, we don't need to be nervous.
What is Ms. Li being nervous about? She's worried she can't pass the exam.
Is Mr. Wang determined to go to the United Kingdom? Yes.
Are you determined to learn English? Yes.
Ms. Li has resolved to study abroad in France, so she's diligently studying French.
Mr. Li uses computers well.
Ms. Zhang writes characters very quickly.
Ms. Li studies English very hard.
I’m not in a good mood today.
Last week I had a Chinese test and today I found out that I didn’t pass.
I’m very disappointed because I've put a lot of effort into it.
I spent a lot of time studying in the library, working on lots of exercises, and practicing with classmates. Maybe I was too nervous when I took the exam.
I’m determined to do better in the future and pass the next test.

word.literal: to stay up very late or all night
